Hiba nodded and opened her notebook. “Are there any checkpoints on the main road this week that usually cause long delays?” she asked, keeping her voice even. “I need to arrive by the morning.”

The agent looked at his computer screen and said, “Some days the highway is slow. People take different exits.”

Hiba asked, “If the road closes unexpectedly, what’s the usual alternative route that drivers use?” She wrote down the names of two towns as he mentioned them. Then she asked, “Do you recommend leaving the evening before?”

A woman waiting behind her leaned in slightly to listen, then looked back at her phone. Hiba didn’t add anything beyond the travel details. When the agent finished explaining, Hiba closed her notebook and said, “Thank you. That’s all I needed.”

She stood, paid the fee for the printed ticket information, and stepped aside so the next customer could approach the desk.

His classmate frowned. “I’d rather not.”

Yazan nodded. “Of course,” he said, and stirred his coffee. A moment later he asked, “Did you see those videos people were sharing last week? The ones everyone argues about?”

The classmate looked down at his cup. “No.”

Yazan leaned back. “I’m not saying anything,” he said. “I’m just curious how you interpret things.” He paused, then said, “Some people defend everything no matter what. Others complain about everything. Which type do you think is worse?”

The classmate exhaled and said, “Let’s talk about work.”

“Sure,” Yazan replied, then immediately asked, “Do you think it’s harder to find work because of decisions made above?” He kept his tone flat and watched his classmate’s face.

The server placed a plate of biscuits on the table, and Yazan reached for one.
